print_settings.Notes:: Remember to print it out of a heat-resistant material, as it is very close to the heat-block.  As this nozzle sits closer to the heat-block than any stock Prusa parts do, I recommend a minimum of ABS in terms of heat-resistance.  Development versions of this cooler in PETG have all suffered significant warping and heat damage - you might get away with a PETG one if you only print PLA as it does cool itself from the inside so long as the part-cooling fan is running, but a PETG one will be damaged after running an ABS print involving higher temperatures and little to no airflow.  I've not personally done any testing to determine how much having an E3D sock may protect the nozzle from radiated heat.

title: Original Prusa i3 MK2 Alternate Part Cooling Nozzle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An alternate part cooling nozzle I designed for my Prusa Original i3 MK2, hopefully to improve part cooling performance on the back-side of parts. It is currently mounted on my printer, but I have not yet completed enough testing to determine if it really is an improvement, or by how much. Please let me know in the comments how it works for you and I will continue to refine the design.

In order to mount this nozzle, you also require a modified extruder cover, which is listed here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2187094 Sorry, I couldn't list both objects together, as that cover is based on Prusa code and carries the GPL, but I wanted to list my part under a non-commercial license. If you would like to license my design for commercial purposes, please contact me.

Update March 27 2017 : Updated model with a variety of small tweaks.

Update April 13 2017 : Further tweaks to the design. Increased clearance around heat-block should reduce warping of nozzle. Modified internal air path. Tweaked nut-trap diameters should hold nuts better.

Update September 22 2017 : Just very minor tweaks this time around - mostly cosmetic or to make printing a bit easier. If you've already got the previous version installed on your printer I would't bother "upgrading". And with this, and all the feedback I've received, I'm finally marking the design as complete.

Thanks go to Spoegler-Engineering, who designed this Titan Extruder upgrade kit for the MK2: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2065461 - that was the inspiration behind this design.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

There is a single built-in support under the right side - it can be cut off with a sharp knife after printing. Or if you prefer, remove it in software and use your slicer supports - just be careful not to let it fill up the interior with support material.

Remember to print it out of a heat-resistant material, as it is very close to the heat-block. As this nozzle sits closer to the heat-block than any stock Prusa parts do, I recommend a minimum of ABS in terms of heat-resistance. Development versions of this cooler in PETG have all suffered significant warping and heat damage - you might get away with a PETG one if you only print PLA as it does cool itself from the inside so long as the part-cooling fan is running, but a PETG one will be damaged after running an ABS print involving higher temperatures and little to no airflow. I've not personally done any testing to determine how much having an E3D sock may protect the nozzle from radiated heat.

comments.author: atlemo

comments.text: You've got your heat block installed pointed in the wrong direction.  And it looks like you must have moved the thermistor and heat-cartridge wires as well, as they're now coming out the wrong side.  The heat-block should be installed such that the short end is across the front, and the screw that clamps the heat cartridge (the screw in the green circle in your picture) is towards the rear of the printer.  And when turned that way, the wires should come out the side away from the PINDA probe.  It also looks like your heat cartridge is not installed all the way into the heat-block.
comments.author: atlemo

comments.text: You are right, I had it this way because of some other fan designs I was testing, completely forgot that it was supposed to be turned! This design is so effective that unless I use the E3D blue sock, I get instant Thermal Runaway :)
comments.author: Cova

comments.text: Thermal runaway after turning the heat-block back to its normal position?  I can believe it with it in the wrong place like that - the one air nozzle is pretty much just cooling the block directly.  But I haven't heard of anyone else having thermal runaway with my nozzle yet, sock or not.  I don't run a sock with it, and I've never gotten that error before - though I do have the 40W heat cartridge.

The spools in the back are not very ergonomic either, and I noticed that others have moved them up higher in the back so they're easier to reach from the front.  I'm thinking of mounting the filament reels on the sides, even though that'll make the printer wider.

comments.author: BruceLayne

comments.text: Thank you for taking the time to respond to my post.  I had already seen your clever designs for the relocated reels of filament.  You were the "others" I was referring to in my original post.  :-)  I'm building a freestanding tower of six Qidi Tech printers (3 tall, back to back) And I don't want to have the reels behind the printers.  Your design has been the inspiration to locate the reels on the sides of the acrylic top cover, similar but rotated 90 degrees from your orientation.  I also think I'll use four roller bearings at the bottom so the reels can be set in place, rather than using a central hub.  This should significantly reduce the time needed to change reels.  I'm designing a small scale additive manufacturing cell, so I expect a lot of reel swapping, so that justifies the time needed to optimize the process.  The outer pair of roller bearings could be adjusted for reels of different widths.  If I produce anything of value, I'll post a thing of my own.  Thanks again for helping to point me in the right direction, and for the inspiring designs.

description.text:
This is a snap-on lens cap for the Sony robust lens protector AKA-MCP1.

Pay attention when removing it from the camera, as if it has too tight a fit, it might pull the lens protector off (possibly damaging its mount). The lens protector has only relatively weak tabs that hold it onto the camera. If the fit is too tight (depends on printer calibration), you may want to file the two holding tabs down a bit.

If you are looking for a lens cap for the underwater housing, there is a design by mann1861 that I've made and it fits nicely. The size of the lens on the underwater housing is different from the lens of the AKA-MCP1 however!

description.text:
Parametric Butt Hinge

This is a parametric butt hinge designed in OpenSCAD, offering a wide range of parameters for customization. The hinge is designed to be printed in one step, but the individual leaves can be printed independently if desired. And in the case of applications that require an external pin, the default fused pin may be disabled, to leave a pin shaft ready to accept an external pin, during post printing assembly.

Note:
In the event that the Thingiverse Customizer is not working, which happens from time to time, you can still open and edit SCAD files directly in an SCAD editor, like OpenSCAD.

Experimental Version:
An experimental version of this model may be found here, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2351153
The experimental version includes additional features that are still being developed, or would otherwise over complicate the base model. I have made the experimental version available for those who would like to brave early access to some of the features that will possibly find there way into the base model, eventually. Please note, the experimental version is not updated as often as the base model, and may still include bugs and untested configurations.

Parameter Overview

Assembly Options

  • Male Leaf Enabled
    Print the male leaf if true, otherwise omit it from the print.

  • Female Leaf Enabled
    Print the female leaf if true, otherwise omit it from the print.

  • Leaf Fillet Enabled
    Enable filleted leaf corners. Aside from aesthetic value, filleted corners can help with warping to a degree.

  • Pin Enabled
    By default, the hinge is designed to be printed in one go, with a hinge pin fused to the female leaf. However, there may be applications where one may prefer to use an external pin. For instance, in the case where a metal pin is preferred for the sake of strength. In applications where an external pin is to be used, the pin may be omitted from the female leaf, by setting "Pin Enabled" to false.

  • Pin Auto Size Enabled
    If true, this will set the pin diameter to the leaf gauge.
    If false, the pin diameter may be specified by the "Pin Diameter" parameter.

  • Pin Shaft Counterbore Enabled
    Cut a counterbore into the end caps of the knuckle joints if true.
    While the pin shaft counterbore may be added even when the internal fused pin is enabled, the primary purpose of the pin shaft counterbore is to allow what ever external pin or bolt is being used in the case of an external pin, to be set flush with the top and bottom edges of the hinge, in the case where the internal pin is disabled, i.e. "Pin Enabled" is false.

  • Fasteners Enabled
    Include fastener holes if true.
    If false, leave the leaves free of fastener holes.

  • Knuckle Gusset Type
    Select whether or not to use knuckle gussets, and if so what type. Knuckle gussets add strength to the transition between the knuckles and the leaves. The length of the knuckle gussets is equal to the fastener margin size, so that the gussets will never overlap any fastener holes.
    There are four styles of knuckle gusset to choose from.

    1. None: No knuckle gussets.
    2. Linear: Straight edge gusset projected from a tangent on the knuckle down to the fastener margin on the leaf.
    3. Circular: Basically a simple fillet, tangential to both the knuckle cylinder and the surface of the leaf.
    4. Parabolic: A vertex form parabola, tangential to the knuckle cylinder, with its turning point tangential to the surface of the leaf at the fastener margin.

  • Throw Angle
    The angle of the hinge joint. The hinge joint range is from +180 degrees fully closed, to -90 degrees fully opened. The default throw angle is 0 degrees, ie. opened flat.
    This can be used either for assembly analysis, or in the case where one wishes to print the hinge standing vertically, it can be used to set a partially closed angle to keep the hinge stable during printing. For vertical printing, an angle of 120 degrees should keep the hinge stable during printing.
    If you just want to print the hinge flat on the build plate, then keep the throw angle at 0 degrees for your printable model.

  • Flip Model
    Rotate the model 180 degrees about the z-axis. This is useful for viewing the top and bottom pin shaft counterbore parameters.

  • Resolution
    The geometric model resolution. Corresponds to the number of sides used to construct cylindrical parts of the model, like the knuckle joint segments, and the leaf fillets.
    For example, a "Resolution" of 8, would specify cylindrical component elements to be constructed from 8 sides. a "Resolution" of 32 would result in 32 sided cylindrical component elements, and so forth.
    For a smooth model, a "Resolution" of 64 and above is recommended. By default "Resolution" is set to 128.

  • Component Color
    This is used purely to color the model in the Thingiverse Customizer. It should not affect the color of the model, printed from a color printer.

Hinge Parameters:

  • Hinge Width
    The width in millimeters, of the entire hinge, from the outer edge of the left leaf, to the outer edge of the right leaf.

  • Leaf Height
    The height in millimeters, of the hinge along the knuckle joint axis.

  • Leaf Gauge
    Defines the thickness in millimeters, of the leaves and the radius of the knuckle joint.

  • Component Clearance
    The inter-component gap in millimeters.
    Recommended values range from 0.3mm for a tight fit, to 0.5mm for easy-er manipulation after printing. Clearance values of 0.3 or below can be challenging to print. I have succeeded in printing a few of these hinges with component clearances of 0.2mm and 0.25mm. However, quite often, sub 0.3mm clearance results in a locked up knuckle joint, where the leaves break before the hinge loosens up. A clearance of 0.4 or greater should release without to much trouble.
    Note: The more knuckle segments there are, the greater the initial joint friction strait off the build plate. So for higher knuckle counts (7 or greater), component clearances of 0.4 or higher, may be required.
    If the knuckle joint is not moving free at 0.4mm or higher, try re-printing slower at a higher resolution, in particular z resolution. Lower temperatures can help as well.
    For PLA, a resolution of x=0.3, y=0.3, and z=0.15, at a speed of 6mm/s or less, with temperature 190 degrees C, seems to support a component clearances of 0.3mm to 0.4mm relatively well.
    All of the sample STL files in the "Thing Files" section, are set to 0.3mm component clearance.

  • Knuckle Count
    The number of knuckle segments in the knuckle joint.
    This number should be an odd number.
    For most applications, a knuckle count of to 3 or 5 should suffice. However, higher knuckle counts can offer increases in strength relative to gauge size and hinge dimensions.

  • Pin Diameter
    Manually specified pin diameter. This value is only used by the model, if "Pin Auto Size Enabled" is set to false.
    If "Pin Auto Size Enabled" is true, then the pin diameter is automatically set to the leaf gauge size.

Pin Shaft Counterbore Parameters:

  • (Top or Bottom) Pin Shaft Counterbore Diameter
    The diameter of the pin shaft counterbore. The counterbore is only added if "Pin Shaft Counterbore Enabled" is set to YES.

  • (Top or Bottom) Pin Shaft Counterbore Depth
    The depth of the pin shaft counterbore cut. The counterbore is only added if "Pin Shaft Counterbore Enabled" is set to YES.

  • (Top or Bottom) Pin Shaft Counterbore Shape
    The shape of the pin shaft counterbore hole. Currently circular, square and hexagonal are supported. In the case of square and hexagonal, the parameter "Pin Shaft Counterbore Diameter", refers to the diameter of a circle inscribed inside the square of hexagon.
    For the square shaped counterbore, this means that the diameter of the counterbore is equal to the size of the sides of the square.
    For the hexagon, the counterbore diameter is equal to the perpendicular distance between any two parallel sides of the hexagon.
    The counterbore is only added if "Pin Shaft Counterbore Enabled" is set to YES.

Fastener Hole Parameters:

  • Fastener Head Type
    Can be set to either counterbore for pan head machine screws, or countersunk for flat countersunk screws.
    The chamfer angle for flat countersunk may be adjusted by varying the other fastener hole parameters. For instance, a thread diameter of 3mm (e.g. M3 machine screws), a head diameter of 9mm, and a countersink depth of 3mm, with give a chamfer angle of 45 degrees.

  • Counter Sink Depth
    The depth below the surface of the leaves to sink the fastener heads.
    For M3 machine screws 2.5 to 2.6 is usually enough.
    If the fastener holes are not countersunk, then there will be mechanical interference between the fastener heads the the opposing leaves when the hinge is closed.

  • Fastener Thread Diameter
    The diameter of the threaded portion of the fastener hole.
    This can be made smaller than the fastener thread in order to support self tapping screws, or larger to give machine screws enough room to pass through.

  • Fastener Head Diameter
    The diameter of the counter sunk head portion of the fastener hole.
    Usually a good idea to make this diameter 0.5mm to 1.0mm larger than the actual fastener head diameter. For M3 machine screws, which typically have 6mm diameter pan heads, an "Fastener Head Diameter" of 7mm works well.

  • Fastener Count
    The number of fastener holes per leaf. The total number of fastener holes in the entire hinge will be "2 x Fastener Count".
    Fastener holes are arranged in one or two columns along the height of the hinge, as specified by "Fastener Column Count".

  • Fastener Column Count
    Specify whether to arrange the fastener holes on a leaf, in one or two columns.

  • Fastener Margin
    The distance from the circumference of the fastener head, to the edge of the leaf.
    Values between 3mm and 5mm are recommended for small to medium gauge hinges.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap Kossel

Resolution:

x = 0.3, y = 0.3, z = 0.15

Infill:

66% or more recommended.

Notes:

Print Speed, Resolution, and Temperature

To get a smooth moving hinge with a small component clearance (0.2 - 0.3), print slowly (4mm/s to 8mm/s), at a high resolution.

I have printed a few of these hinges in PLA at 190 degrees Celsius, with 0.2mm, 0.25mm, and 0.3 mm component clearances, using a 0.3mm nozzle, and a z resolution of 0.15.

Support

Supports are required to support the curved regions of the knuckle joint near the build plate.

For small gauge hinges, you could probably get way with no support at all. But for larger gauges of about 5mm and above, you will probably want to add a little support from at least 50 degrees for a nice neat curved finish.

No support is required for the internals of the knuckle joint segments, as long as reasonable component clearances of between 0.2mm to 0.3mm are used.

Build Plate Adhesion

If you have a heated build plate, then you should get away with a brim or a skirt.

If you are printing on an un-heated build plate, you may experience warping, in which case a raft should help, at the expense of a poorer quality finish on the bottom surface.

For component clearances less than 0.4, the knuckle joints can be quite tough to free up. There is also a risk of the leaves breaking if you try to free up the knuckle joints with too much force.

For simple hinges with 3 to 5 knuckle joints, and a component clearance of 0.4mm or more, you may find that the hinge moves fairly freely strait off the build plate.

If the hinge is locked up after printing, which will most certainly be the case for component clearances of 0.3mm or less, there is something you can do to ease the process of loosening up the knuckle joint. What I find works fairly well is to soften the hinge in hot water for about 30 seconds, to a minute, and then very quickly take the hinge out of the hot water and rapidly try to move the knuckle joint. Because the hinge will be soft after removing from the hot water, care needs to be taken not to let the leaves of knuckle joint bend. If it looks like any part of the hinge is bending, put it back in the hot water and try again in 30 seconds to a minute, until the knuckle joint begins to loosen up.

I have never measured the temperature of the water. But for hinges printed using PLA, I find hot water from the bathroom tap seems to do the trick. The hot water in the case of my bathroom tap is just too hot for sustained contact with my hand, but cool enough that I can quickly reach in and remove the submerged hinge without being seriously burned.

If you are printing in ABS, you will need significantly hotter water, perhaps close to boiling, if not hotter. In which case, gloves and great care will be required in order to prevent injury.
OpenSCAD Fusion 360 animation, showing the throw range of the hinge.

comments.text:
• I can't give you any STL files, because it is a parametric model. Parametric models require the consumer to set the parameters, and then generate STL files based on the configured parameters.

  • SCAD models 'are' the standard for parametric models on Thingiverse.

  • You can't open SCAD models in slicing software like CURA. You can open SCAD models with SCAD supported CAD software, like OpenSCAD, or the Thingiverse Customizer.

  • The Thingiverse Customizer hasn't worked for a few months. Content creators have no control over this. However, it is not a problem, because you can just open SCAD files in OpenSCAD directly, and set the parameters there.

  • I'm not so sure there are tons of others though. I stand to be corrected, but at the time of this writing, I think this may be the only parametric hinge model on Thingiverse. I'd be keen to take a look at any others that you find though. Parametric models are more complex to create than static models. I'd be keen to see how other designers have implemented parametric hinges, if you can find any others.

description.text: Lion2 Key Chain 50x50x4mm

print_settings.Notes:: I scaled mine down to 96% in the slicer and used the extra space for a brim to prevent warping. It also provides margin against skipped steps in case the printer's endstops aren't precisely located and an axis bottoms out. Be careful not to pry the brim away from the rest of the part as it will likely peel the first layer with it. Use multiple perimeters for strength. Infill is negligible except for creating the top layers for each base.stl

description.text:
A lamp styled like a traditional japanese andon (行灯). I used this light bulb socket but I provided the .stp file for the main post if you want to modify it for a different one. More picts and info on my blog.

The lamp measures 285mm X 200mm x 200mm but is printable on a typical 200mm x 200mm bed. Just rotate the long vertical members 45° to fit along a diagonal.

Print 2x base.stl, 4x column.stl, 22x spar.stl, 1x maincolumn.stl or make your own, 2x key.stl to connect it, and optionally 2x frame.stl for mounting a picture or optically diffusive fabric. I used vellum paper in an inkjet printer, after lightening and desaturating the image slightly and being careful not to smudge the print while it dried.

The columns connect to the base by tapered dovetail joints, and the spars are inserted into slots but are non-structural. Glue is optional, but recommended for attaching the main column to the base via the key joint.

Use ABS or PETG for key.stl and the main post to avoid softening in the bulb's heat. I'd recommend not leaving it on and unattended for long periods of time either way. Mine just happens to be a few feet from a fire extinguisher.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select (V1)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I scaled mine down to 96% in the slicer and used the extra space for a brim to prevent warping. It also provides margin against skipped steps in case the printer's endstops aren't precisely located and an axis bottoms out. Be careful not to pry the brim away from the rest of the part as it will likely peel the first layer with it. Use multiple perimeters for strength. Infill is negligible except for creating the top layers for each base.stl

Left-to-right: As printed, sanded, stained, and coated in varnish.

If you use wood-filament, sanding and staining will bring out a more wood-esque surface finish. I sanded to 800 grit without removing so much material that the layer striations disappear- the right amount of sanding makes them look similar to wooden grain. Additionally, you may want to refine the fit between the joints to minimize gaps on the exterior. They have a ±.15mm tolerance but my printer still resulted in more of a press-fit for the main columns, mostly because of the radius at the base of the dovetail joints.

description.text: Here are two decorated teacups with matching saucers. They were calculated with the openSCAD code from thing:2180347-Teacups with Matching Saucers. The program uses decorated spheres as templates. Any roughly spherical object will do, decorations can be either embossed or incised. Two nearly spherical polyhedra were used as templates - one based on a 632 electron solution to the Thomson problem - thing:393712 -; the second using one of Hart's propello polyhedra - thing:1136184. Details are in the openSCAD code.

description.text:
With all the Micro SD cards in the camera bag, I was looking for a way to organize them, keep them from getting lost in the crevices and provide some way of determining which are empty, and which have been used. This is what I ended up with - a disc that stores 5 Micro SD cards, and you can keep track of the used ones by turning them over when you put them back in. The built in indexing will keep the disc from rotating accidentally, stopping with the opening over a card slot for card access, and in between for storage.

UPDATE : While printing a few more of these for my various camera bags, I found the retention fingers were breaking off more often than I liked, so I changed the design a bit, and added slot identifiers on the front to better distinguish between cards.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

I printed this using a 0.4 mm nozzle in ABS so that the retention fingers were flexible enough for assembly. I printed with a bit higher temp than normal, ~240, to get better inter-layer bonding - the retention pillars seem to hold up better that way. Also, I needed to use ABS Juice to get the first layer to adhere adequately, similar to any ABS print.

I printed the tops in PLA, as that was the color filament I had.
To assemble, just snap the two pieces together.
I designed this in Fusion 360 - good piece of software, that!
I joined the separate meshes (6 or 7) into one mesh using Rhino.
Needs plenty of support material...

title: Simple wall mount for Apple Airport express late 2013

description.text: Well, needed to mount my Apple Airport Express (purchased late 2013) and found a very wonderful design by Pitoya: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:146026. Now, they do mention that their design has some drawbacks... mainly that the light is hidden and that the design needs to be printed bigger (101%) to actually fit. Well, I printed it 100% and it doesn't fit [see my last photo]. While Pitoya's is a beautiful design, I decided to make my own and a very simple one. Also, I prefer gluing things to the wall rather than screwing them in. Very simple and plain, this design fits my needs and works out great for me. I hope it does as well for you; however, if you want to mod it, please feel free to use SolidWorks source file I've added.

title: Iron Man wearable helmet Mark 42  Mk 42

description.text:
This is a fully printable, full size Iron Man Mark 42 helmet!
You can read my many updates down below on how I got to this point.
Print out the parts, orient them as you wish, paint them and wear it!
The photos I posted are of a scaled down print, about 50% size. Look at the Makes for what a full size looks like! Please post pictures if you make it! I really would like to see how they turn out, thanks.

UPDATES on how I did this:
Part of the chin piece, the cheek area I guess, was too thin, at full size only one line thick (with a .4mm nozzle). I thickened it using the "make solid" tool in Meshmixer and cleaned it up with 3D builder. I printed it at 30% scale and it came out pretty good. I will post pictures if I print it full size.

Update: added my repairs for the other files. You may notice some look smoother than they were before, Meshmixer does this and I could not revert it but in print previews it looks fine.

Update: I just printed the chin piece, it printed very well but does not appear large enough to be worn. Keep in mind that you will have to scale this to fit your head. My guess is 150%.

Update: I printed the faceplate piece as well at this size. It is indeed too small to wear. Also I will probably update the chin piece with one that is less low-poly, it looks odd when printed. If you have a good way to measure this and estimate a scale that would make it full size please comment.

Update: Added a higher-poly chin piece. - It has several issues, printing not recommended

Update: Replaced the higher-poly chin with a much better more-poly-smooth version. There are still small holes by the cheek area I am working on.

Update: New version of chin-high-poly-smooth. This is probably as good as I will get it.

Update: Added a smoother version of Bo13on's hollow remix.

Update: Added pictures and video of a 50% scale full print. Video here: https://goo.gl/photos/pN9vGhxjybhhzgdY7

Update: Replaced files with 130% scaled ones. It is now full size.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Print at 100% for a full size helmet. Print a 50% for a nice desk model. Use supports when needed.

comments.text: Hi, I have just printed all four parts. scaled to 1.25 on Repetier Host using CuraEngine. the face plate, chin and neck came out great but the top has this large flat plate that stops you from sticking your head in it. little disappointing after 30 hours of printing :( any idea what that is about?
comments.author: Bo13on

comments.text: Hmm, as you probably read, I did not print that part yet. I do see the large flat part you are talking about, I did not change that area at all, both previous versions of this model had that piece and I assumed it would not be a problem. Now that you mention it, it does look oddly placed. Sorry you wasted so much time on it! If you can fix it, be my guest, if not, I think I can. Hopefully you can just reprint that piece. Can you please upload some pictures of it so I can see how the other parts look at this size. Also, if you don't use that piece can you fit your head in? is 125% enough? Really sorry you printed it all out!!!
comments.author: Bo13on

comments.text: I uploaded all of the photos. Apologies, im not trying to be edgy or cool, they all just uploaded sideways. This is the third time i have re scaled and printed some parts. started at 15% then as it was clearly too small i printed at 30% and felt that it looked huge so i scaled back to 25% and now the majority fits snugly, just enough space for some padding but the head top has the plate inside. Maybe i should have stuck to 30% but i didn't want to look llike a lollypop

I will try again with others programs. 130% is probably the way to go, once I fix that piece as much as I can I will reupload the files scaled up and then print myself.

title: OpenRC F1 Wheels for F103 Tires

description.text:
These are wheels designed to fit F103 sized tires. The diameter of F103 tires is closer to the 3d printed tires than F104. The fronts are a little narrow- but the rears are wide and fantastic. These look like 2017 F1 car tires. The car drives much better with these than with 3D printed stuff.

I added some superglue to the bead of the tire to ensure they stay in place but you might get away without this. The tires fit well with no glue- especially the fronts.

author: sciamop

description.text:
This is the second revised version of my 'Predator' quadcopter. The two words I have designed around are modularity and durability, there are now mounting holes at the end of the arms for prop guards as well as extra landing/stability legs.  
I would recommend using either metal/nylon screws, however you could just as well use (strong!) cable ties to hold everything together. The dimension of the main holes are ~4.2mm diameter +/- a couple hundred mics depending on your printer.  
I will hopefully be adding more varied and useful attachments for the body of the quad and the arms.  
This is more of a functional quad rather than particularly light i.e. when I was designing it strength was more of a concern than mass, however of course mass was a large factor when making decisions.

ABS
I recommend printing everything at 200 microns layer height, with 50% infill for the arms, 35-50% for the plates and 30+% for the landing gear, with 3 skins.

comments.author: Josecmh

comments.text: Sorry I took so long, I used cura. You can use cura, just unplug the extruder motor and set all temperatures to or room temperature. Don't use more than 2 layers and use a very low layer height so the laser remains focused. The best thing you can do is experiment. The main concept is to set the fan to 100% constantly and use a very low print speed but high movement speed so the laser can't burn while the extruder head is moving to the next part of the print. It works very well but you can't get grey scale, for that you need some proper software that you will need to pay for, this is only good for black and white images like yin and yang.

title: Tevo Tarantula Control Knob
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I am printing parts for my Tevo Tarantula in purple so that it can have a purple/black theme going on. To that end, I wanted a purple knob. So... I made one. Or rather, I made two. The first version is a straight sided knob with a hollow interior like the original knob, with a slight indent on top. The second version is tapered, like the original, but is filled in instead, with a flat top.

On the second version, I still had the wall thickness set to 0.5mm (from the first version) so you can see a ring around the knob where the hollow portion and the solid portions meet. Thicker walls should prevent that, but I like the way it looks - kind of like a top hat - so.... it stays.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Both versions need to be printed upside down to eliminate the need for support material. The second version does not need any support material at all. For the first version, though, the choice is yours. If you do not use support, the first layer of the indent sags a little (as you can see in my photo - black nail polish easily covers that up) but if you do use support, with it being such a small section, it is a PAIN to remove.

For the first version, with the hollow section, I suggest 0.5mm wall width.

The first version will need to be slightly drilled out to 15/64" to properly fit the shaft of the potentiometer. I recommend drilling first to 7/32" before going down to 15/64". The second version is a perfect press fit.

What these do is allow for retention of a handheld light as well as a semi two-handed grip on a firearm while still being able to manipulate the light.

title: MP Select Mini Strain Relief Extruder Heater / Thermocouple

description.text:
If you watch closely during large movements in the X-direction, you will see both the Extruder Heater and Extruder Thermocouple wires move and are being fatigued / worn-out at the heater block. This "strain relief" uses two zip ties to secure the wires and prevent fatigue at the point of termination.

Bowden Tube "Push-to-Connect" fitting must be removed by pulling the fan and using a 1.5mm allen key to loosen the clamp holding in the Bowden Tube Push-to-Connect fitting.

Create extra slack for the Heater and Thermocouple wires by unwinding some of the "spiral wrap", this is so the flex within the system is taken up in this area. See image.

SEE IMAGES TO REFERENCE FINAL INSTALLATION

author: steelmesh

title: Sturdy Type B / 2020 frame brace (90 deg) for M5 screws

description.text:
As most of the cheap-ish 2020 90 deg frame braces I ordered were seriously lacking quality, I just designed my own.

This is a stury 90 degree frame brace for Type B and 2020 extrusions. Small footprint of only 25x25mm.

It works with most types of screwheads and will accept a washer with d2=10mm.

The guide is 5.6mm wide, which will leave some play in the groove.

I print this design with supports, no real post processing needed as the connection points disappear in the extrusion groove when screwed down. 3 shells and 25% infill are sufficient, but dont use cheap, glossy PLA for high stress application as it might be too soft.

Designed to be used with M5x10 screws.

Enjoy.

author: jaredten

description.text: voici un cache arrière avec sortie alimentation

title: robust e3dv6 mount / X-carriage for Geetech Prusa I3 with autolevel-sensor and fan-duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Dear all,

the e3d mounts I found on thingiverse didn't satisfy me own needs, so I decided to create my own version.

My design-goals have been the following:

  • most important: easy to print and robust
    • only the two e3d-clamps require printing with ABS
    • if ABS warps or layer do not stick together strongly, it does NOT matter. just print:)The design ensures that even lazy printed ABS clamps work nicely.
  • the print-nozzle is mostly visible to check its proper operation
  • it shall accomodate 18mm auto-level-sensor
  • it shall provide cooling-fan
  • it should run smoothly on the x-axis and accomodate "SC8UU" mounting-block. I original SC8UU are somewhat to lengthy, so I created a shorter version. Please see here for the block: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2303766
  • it is a complete solution (cooling, plate, abl-sensor, ed3-mount,..)
  • just made my very few prints and it works nicely

Feedback and wishes are appreciated - positive as well as negative.

If you think something is bad on the design I would appreciate direct message first:)

If you think 12mm ABL sensor version is required or you can recommend another fan-duct, please let me know.

More pictures and assembly-instructions will be uploaded over time.

thanks

christian

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Only two parts are recommended to print in ABS - the clamps for the E3D head.
Anything else, even the x-carriage/plate can be printed in PLA

Assembly

SC8UU alignment
It is very important to ensure easy movement of the x-carriage.
I found this procedure useful:

  • assemble the whole thing, including fan, sensor, e3dv6 and sc8uu
  • do NOT yet tighten the screws for sc8uu!
  • mount on your printer x-axis 8mm rods and ensure all runs smoothly. If it does not yet run smootly, loose the screws somewhat more.
  • once all runs smoothly, tighten the SC8uu screws and it shall still run smoothly.

Mounting
To reduce weight I have decided to replace most 4mm screws with 3mm variants. I am still not yet clear if this was a good design or give you guys issues when assembling the part. Feedback appreciated here. Only 2 screws are 4mm and those are the ones fixing the E3D clamps. All other screws are 3mm in diameter. The main reason for choosing 4mm for the clamps was pure availability - the 4mm screws need a length of 65-70mm. And its difficult to find 3mm screws having this length.

This is a mounting bracket to mount an MKS Sbase 1.3 board to a frame with RAMPS mounting holes. There is another set of holes I added but honestly have no idea what they are for. I just copied the dimensions from my frame. The bracket can be mounted vertically or horizontally. I've offset the mounting holes to allow for more clearance at the edges of the board.

Also designed a cover that works well.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194381

EDIT April 22, 17: Redesigned the mount. Made the hexagons much larger. Changed the standoffs to a more durable design. Added holes for M3 nuts to secure the board (and top cover).

EDIT: Sept 17, 17. Fixed a screw hole that was off. Added a version w/ vertical support. Also added a .step file if you want to customize it @ all.

author: Superpoo

title: Simple Zero Ooze Dual Extruder - CRUX - no electronics, motors, or changed firmware
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 10/23/17: The mechanism still works great almost 4 months later. The only thing that could be improved is the cooling fan mount, because it tend to slip down if the screws aren't tight. I made a little piece to keep it upright that I will include in the files.

Update 7/2/17: Updated the hotend holder cap (for normal sized hotends) to be more form-fitted in order to reduce cooling of the heat block. Changed the retaining arm for the extruder part to be less fragile and easier to assemble.

Update 6/18/17: I changed the design to work with either volcano hotends or normal sized hotends (just not both at once).

Update 6/17/17: The current version only works with the volcano hotends, I am working on a version for the regular sized hotends.

If you have ever tried a dual extrusion print, you know it can be a huge pain. The other nozzle bumps into what you are printing, it oozes all over your prints, and has to be primed before printing, which wastes plastic.
And if you try a mixing nozzle, it will constantly clog if you don't print with one of the colors for a while, one color will bleed into the next, and it can't use materials that aren't similar, for instance dissolvable support or flexible materials.

The CRUX dual extruder system eliminates all of these problems with a super cheap (less than $10!) and simple solution that requires no special knowledge to operate: No added motors, electronics, or firmware. Just build it and attach it, and change a few slicing settings. You can see the results in the images. The frog was printed at 0.3 layer height, so it does look rough but it was just for testing (I will upload more when I make more cool stuff).

Here's how it works:
The two hotends are at an angle to each other, and rotate together on two bearings. Rotating the hotends causes one to be vertical when printing, and the other to be "capped" with a metal strip, which prevents oozing. In order to rotate these hotends back and forth, the system uses a mechanism similar to a bike brake cable, but using a piece of filament and a bowden tube instead.
The carriage is switched remotely by the extruder. When the extruder gear rotates one direction (extruding), the mechanism pushes on the piece of filament, causing that hotend to rotate to the vertical position. While the extruder keeps extruding, the force remains constant, holding the hotend in place.
When the extruder rotates the other direction by 80mm (retracting), it will pull on the filament, switching to the other hotend. When the extruder un-retracts, it will switch back. The other extruder does not need any modifications.
The extruder mechanism allows for normal retractions (~ 6mm or less) without switching. This way you can just set your "extruder switch retraction distance" to 90mm in the slicer, and it will just work.

The youtube video below also kind of explains how it works (it is a bit old and describes problems that are now fixed):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-pla2nTOf0U

Here is the parts list, not including the extruders and hotends (fits e3d hotend style and stock tarantula extruder):

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1BHZdDf7nSVykozLdog23PVMdhgn_bmm2i0PQVCDQTcQ/edit?usp=sharing

Printed parts (see combined file for all on one build plate):
1x carriage
1x hotend holder pt 1 v2
1x hotend holder pt 2
1x hotend holder cap

Instructions for printing:
-The filament must be loaded all the way into each hotend before printing. You especially need to check this after stopping a print halfway through, since one of the filaments will be retracted by 90mm.
-If you are having trouble with the first layer not sticking, it's probably because your nozzles aren't level. Level the nozzles as best you can, and if it still doesn't work, try using a raft, which will make it much easier to get everything to stick.
-Don't be alarmed when you hear the extruder "clicking". The mechanism is making that noise, and it is normal. The two wheels with magnets are skipping past each other.
-You probably want to assign the extruder with the mechanism attached to the second extruder, so you don't constantly use it when you are doing single color prints. And you probably also want to use it for the part in the model that uses the least material, again so you don't constantly use the mechanism.

I have been using the original clip on various spools. It fit some early ones I had but doesn't fit well on anything from Makergeeks (which I have a lot of) nor various other sources. So I tweaked it up because I got tired of the old ones falling off the newer spools.

I have tested them on the following spools:
MakerGeeks (newer)
3 Different Chinese import spool types
MatterHacker (older)
FormFutura (older)

Do not fit or at least don't hold well on:
MakerGeeks (some older, he seemed to use several spool suppliers a few years ago)
MatterHacker (newer)
FormFutura (newer)
T-Glase small reels

It can be made to fit MatterHacker newer ones by extending the locking tab because the spool rim is longer than MakerGeeks. The rim thickness is the same between the two so it should be an easy mod.

author: SevierCoy

description.text:
My oldest camera is from approximately 1912 and it was made for 122 type roll film, which hasn´t been produced since 1971. There are adapters to use 120-sized roll film, which is still widely available, but that solution will not cover the full picture area, which is huge.

So what´s the solution? Either use single sheets of film and load your camera in the dark before and after each shot like I´ve done a few times, which is ok for testing, but quite inconvenient - or you can slice&roll your own 122 film.

However for that you will need at least two spools. My camera only had one, but at least that one made it possible it to measure the correct dimensions for making more.

Instructions:
Print with at least 50% infill. Press the two halves together, use a few drops of glue to secure them if you like. The ends of the spool are quite thin, so depending on your print material, it might be recommendable to use black spray paint on the finished spool to make it more light proof.

description.text:
This was made for my old lady who is in the Red Hats. After printing, a pin back was glued to the hat so she can wear it on her outfit (costume as I call it).

I can already hear the question. What the heck does a Christmas Tree have to do with a Red Hat Ladies pin? Nothing much. But, I did use the base of the tree as a starting point for the hat so its only fair to list the tree as a source.

The bow from the package should be fairly obvious in its use.

Cardinal not included (sorry, only photo I had of the completed hat).

I printed the hat with the Red Crystal Series PLA that came with the December GeekBox and the ribbon from MakerGeek's Purple ABS.

Be sure to print the PLA hot and slow to get the maximum translucency out of it.

Pay attention to the bow orientation on the build platform. There is a taper on one inside edge that fits the curve of the hat. If you print it upside down (ie taper down) you won't get a nice fit. Also by printing it with the taper up, you have a nice finished top so almost no finishing needed.

Hello, We are First Lego League team 1107, CROSS FIRE. We are a team of 10 boys ages 9 to 14. This year's challenge (from the League) was Natures Fury and all the teams had to come up with an innovation. Our innovation was the fire buggy, which uses 3D printed parts, along with Lego NXT parts, to allow firefighters to create a "Fire Buggy". For our Fire Buggy we used an old Power Wheels. We even showed our Fire Buggy to real firefighters. This is a work in progress, and we will be improving the parts. Firebuggy1: is a bracket that holds an NXT brick
Firebuggy2: is a bracket that holds a UV (Distance) sensor
Firebuggy3: is a bracket that holds an NXT motor We are still working on the steering mechanisms. These parts were made by team members, but, this thingiverse account is maintained by our coach.

description.text:
This is an enclosure I have designed for the DetectIR tester available from AnalysIR. Its a fantastic little board which runs great of AAA batteries.

AnalysIR make a whole range of fantastic range of high quality IR boards ready to run on Arduino, ESP8266, Photon and even RaspPi.

------> Check them out at https://www.analysir.com <------

I designed the enclosure so I could have a self contained IR tester for use in home automation deployments. When sending IR signals over long cable runs or through Cat5 baluns having a quick way to confirm IR signal is working can save allot of time.

All you do is turn the tester on and then point your IR source at the tester. The Red LED with light up if an inferred signal is being detected.

The build also requires the following
1x DetectIR board from AnalyisIR
1x AAA battery holder
1x Slide switch
Soldering Iron

The build is quite simple. Just following the picture, you can see I have wired the black GND wire through the switch and to the P1 terminal on the PCB. The Red Vcc wire is wired directly to the V_ALT connector.

Sliding the switch completes the circuit and powers the DetectIR on.

Links to parts
DetectIR PCB
https://www.analysir.com/blog/product/detectir-advanced-ir-receiver-modules/

Switch

description.text:
The question was how to mount a tracker with no or just minor interference to both compasses.
I checked several positions and their influence on compass reading. Above the battery seem to be a valuable position.
It should be easy to mount or unmount because of packing reasons.
The idea was to use a kind of back pack adapter, snap it onto the battery and fix a tracker using velcro.
You can switch the mavic on/off when mounted, but the battery LEDs keeps invisible.
When I decided to upload it to thingiverse, I saw pcardon had already created a similar design. Maybe we are on the same wavelength

Video of it walking for the first time can be seen here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=882c_ENxSAo

This Hexabot was designed using Shapr3D on my iPad Pro. This took 8 revisions and 32 days to model, print and assemble. This was designed to use the identical electronics used in the Trossen Robotics PhantomX. Please visit the PhantomX Product page at Trossen Robotics for the electronics parts list as I used the exact ones.

I have installed the electronics and ran the test program to verify basic setup. At some point I will attempt to program this.

Uses mostly 2mm x 6 and 2mm x 8 hardware. There are a few pieces of 3mm hardware. The toes of the feet were designed to use 1/4" rubber vacuum caps that you can pick up at most automotive parts stores, this gives the bot a softer walk but more importantly some grip on hard floors.

This design was inspired by the PhantomX, but only thing duplicated was the electronics which were all purchased at Trossen Robotics.

The file labeled RH_Hexabot_Complete_v8 is not meant to be printed, it is for visual reference only.

UPDATE 9-26-17: I have switched to Fusion 360 and have been experimenting with the features and have been able to animate the legs to show the range of motion.

description.text:
This device is a protection for a 3D printer when a power outage occurs.  If the power goes out, the printer will not be turned back on when the power comes back.  
The scenario I have experienced is the following.  I was printing an object using a laptop.  While printing, the power went out. The Arduino stayed powered by the laptop.  When the power came back, the extruder was turned back on but no filament was pushed in by the extruder.  The result was a ruined J-Head.  The filament was burned solid in the extruder.  I had to replace it.  
When power is applied to the device, the push button must be depressed to have power on the output terminals.

Be careful when building this device. It deals with a lot of currents: 16A per printer. It is enough to catch on fire if not assembled properly or the right components are not used. This device can drive only one device at the time. If you want to drive two printers, you shall replace the wiring gauge, the relay, the switches, etc. Shame on me! I did not print the case. This case cost less than $5. It simply does not worth it designing one and printing it. Bill Of Materials
  • 1 relay NVF4-4C-Z30A-12VDC. It is a relay used for cars. [K1]
  • 1 bolt and nut to attach the relay to the case
  • 1 four posts terminal [CONN2]
  • 1 two posts terminal [CONN1]
  • 1 switch with a 12VDC light [S3/GL1]
  • 1 push button normally open [S1]
  • 1 12VDC light [GL2]
  • 1 switch to select which printer is active (The one I got has a neutral position.) [S2]
  • 1 12 ohms 1/2 watt resistors [R2]
  • 2 36 ohms 1/4 watt resistor [R1/R3]
  • Solderless terminals.
  • 6 feet of 12 AWG wire
  • 1 Hammond case 1591XXSSFLBK
    • The resistors are required only if you are using a 13.8VDC power supply.

This is a mount for the Arduino Uno for the Shapeoko2 intended for the right Y axis motor mount plate, as shown in Wiring Option 3 here: http://docs.shapeoko.com/wiring_3.html This design was based off of pieces from the following Things:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33327
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:114500 I've found the board screws in nicely to the plastic using a short #2 screw (around 1/4" or so) like this one: http://www.grainger.com/product/Wood-Screw-1LA56?s_pp=false

Printed on a makerbot replicator2.  A sketchup file and a STL file are provided.  The STL file has already been run through netfab and had repairs made, so use it for printing (it has repaired in the name).  The sketchup file is just provided in case you want to make modifications.  In that case, you should probably run it through netfab after you export to STL.  
The outer holes are meant to be through-bolt holes for whatever fastener you deem appropriate.  The inner posts are meant to be used with small plastic self tapping screws - something like a #2 plastic screw might work.

description.text:
80mm fans vary greatly, and the part with the original didn't fit any of the four I tried. I've therefore made a parameteric one in OpenSCAD.

I hope the parameter names make sense, and I've added some comments, but just ask if anything isn't clear.

Update: Now updated so it works with the Thinigverse customizer.

This item is a simple top that has a small indent in the top to facilitate stacking one top on another. I home injection molded this part as I have some of my other Thingiverse parts. More info on my injection molding process is available at http://www.scorchworks.com

Although I am providing a STL and Alibre part files I actually hand wrote the G-code for creating the mold. Note that the point on which the top spins is created with spherical features. I created the spherical mold features by plunging centercutting ball nose bits to the appropriate depth. The mold feature for the top handle was created by cutting circles at increasing depth with a tapered ballnose bit (a Dremel bit that I picked up at a home improvement store).
I also engraved text on the top surface linking back to my Thingiverse page. The text was added using g-code generated by F-Engrave.

EN : I simply loaded both files in windows 3D builder and removed the intersection.
I'm afraid the triangle inside the triforce will not hold, will update if it happen, I give you the updated (uglier but less risky) model anyway
Edit better version, but I con't print it myself because my printer bed is too small
Created a two part print, with the help of a chess set

Edit 2 the small triangle is very fragile and we can see a square in the bottom part, should be fixed now

FR : j'ai juste mis les deux sources dans le programme 3D de windows et fait "soustraire".
J'ai des doutes sur le fait que le triangle au centre de la triforce va tenir donc j'ai crée une second avec une triforce plus moche mais plus solide. Je vous tiens au courant dès que j'imprime.
edit : meilleure version, mais je ne peut pas l'imprimer a cause de la taille de mon imprimante
J'ai fait une version en 2 part avec l'aide d'un jeu d'echec qui venait en plusieur parts
edit 2 le petit triangle est très fragile, il tiens mais je ne le toucherais pas trop
Un rectangle apparait dans celui du bas, j'ai réglé le fichier

author: adiasmesquita

description.text:
This is a dismountable 3D printer enclosure I built specially for my E3D BigBox printer, but you can adapt it easily for any other size printer. It can be disassembled and stored when not in use. The principle is simple; the case is built with square (and hollow) aluminum tubes connected with 3D printed corner pieces. In every corner piece (except for the roof), I glued a small (10x10x4 mm) neodymium magnet (see the pictures), making it very easy to dismantle or rebuild the case. The whole enclosure can be built-up within a minute.

The side perspex panels are mounted with magnets so they can be taken off in case you need to access the printer for maintenance.

You can place a 80mm fan in order to regulate the temperature, but I found that the temperature hardly comes higher than 35°C, even when printing with the heated bed at 120°C.

Printing filament used: PLA and Taulman Alloy 910

Print settings.

I printed the corner pieces and the hinges with Taulman Alloy 910. You can try another material, but Taulman did the job for me. Don't use PLA since it is too brittle !
I printed the corner pieces horizontal with raft and support, just to be sure that the pieces were 100% straight, because Alloy 910 did tend to warp a little on my PEI bed. Infill was at 20%. The parts fit tightly in the aluminum profiles, I had to hammer them in. Don't hammer directly on the pieces, but use for example a piece of wood to dampen the blows (or use a dead blow hammer).

Aluminum bars needed for BigBox

The aluminum bar size I used is 15 x 15 mm

Front / back panels

  • 4x upright bar 690 mm high
  • 4x horizontal bar 595 mm long

Side panels

  • 4x upright bar 690 mm high
  • 4x horizontal bar 530 mm long

Roof panel

  • 2x front / back bar 595 mm long
  • 2x side bars 560 mm long
Magnets
  • 16 x cube magnets (10 x 10 x 4) mm for the the corner pieces
  • 12 x round magnets (12 mm diameter, 1 mm thick) for the doors and the side panels
Perspex panels

Clear perspex for front doors and roof.

  • 2 x Doors 295 x 688
  • 1 x Roof 558 x 594

Channel plate for back doors and side panels

  • 2 x Doors 295 x 688
  • 2 x Side panel 528 x 688
3D printed parts:

Taulman Alloy 910 or any other high tensile strength polymer.

  • 4 x Roof corner piece
  • 4 x Front and back panels corner piece
  • 4 x Side panels corner piece
  • 4 x Hinge doorpost left
  • 4 x Hinge doorpost right
  • 4 x Hinge door left
  • 4 x Hinge door right

PLA or any other (cheap) material:

  • 8 x Door and side panel knob
  • 2 x Doors upper magnet holder
  • 8 x Side panel magnet holder
  • 4 x Roof panel bearer corner piece
  • 4 x Roof panel bearer middle piece
  • 1 x fan protector (for 80mm fan)
Just a simple skid for the under side of the mini talon wing to protect exposed hardware. Simple, tough and effective.

title: Y-Belt tension and parallelizer for Anet A6/A8

description.text:
As most of you know the Anet has neither a "real" possibility to adjust belt tension in y-direction nor the belt runs parallel between stepper and pulley.
There are already some solutions concerning tension adjustment or using a "spacer" to make the belt run parallel but I tried to do both in one solution.
I made a two part solution as you can see in the pictures. I printed them with no supports and it simply worked for me.
I use the h-frame as shown on the pictures. See the orientation to get the right distance.

Edit : The Anet belt is different to my glasfibre reinforced belt. I added a version for the ANet Belt that is named accordingly. The difference in height 1,7 mm vs. 1,3 mm (Anet vs. glasfibre belt).
Edit 2: Added a version for a one-piece h-frame-replacement that reduces the height 3 mms. There will be no version for Anet belt of this one because before you buy an h-frame replacement you should get a better belt first.

You'll need:

2x M3 nut (spare from Anet)
2x M3 screw (M3x30 spare from Anet)

Have fun...

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

30%

description.text:
A salt shaker, made with OpenSCAD.

The idea was to use the linear_extrude module with the twist parameter to create a "screw". It turns out that it's not a good idea. That feature is quite messy, create concave surface and it's hard to control.

I found a screw library http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793 but I'm not satisfy with the result. It doesn't respect its parameter. The screw is longer then its length parameter, wider than its radius parameter, etc. I will either try to understand the library better, find another one or write my own.

I found an alternative to OpenSCAD called ImplicitCAD, but the project is still quite immature. I will wait before investing time learning that new software.

[2017-03-24] Uploaded version 3. It's the same shaker, but this time it's using my helix_extrude library (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2200395). It's the first time I use that library, so it might have some issue. OpenSCAD render the STL without any warning, but Slic3r warns about some auto-repaired errors.

[2017-06-15] I finally received my Prusa i3 MK3S! Yay! I tried to print this thing and I quickly realised that it's unprintable. I'm currently doing adjustments. I will upload a new version when I will be satisfied.

[2017-06-16] I created my version 4 with the corrections required to make it printable. I printed without supports, it works beautifully.
There is what I modified:

  • Less tolerance in the threads: I used Angus' tolerance gauge to find what would be the best tolerance to use: youtu.be/TYuLVN3YHw8
  • I make the threads in the inside of the shaker goes all the way down. Starting the threads in mid air was causing trouble with printing.
  • I made the tip of the hole in a steeper angle to facilitate printing.

1. Clean the small holes at the top of the shaker. A small Allen key works nicely.
  2. Put the cap at the bottom and screw it in using the handle of a fork or a spoon.
  3. Screw the cap in and out a few times to loosen the threads. The cap should go a few millimetres deeper than the base of the shaker.
  4. Remove the cap.
  5. Hold the shaker upside down covering the holes with the palm of your hand, to prevent the salt from leaking while filling it up.
  6. Add some salt in it. Do not fill it completely, about half way should be enough.
  7. Screw the cap all the way in.

WARNING: PLA plastic is known to be food safe. However, the threads in the plastic are likely to trap bacteria. I would not recommend using any 3D printed parts to hold food. Use at your own risk.

I'm an OpenSCAD enthusiast. I like challenges, like creating usable threads using the basic functionalities of OpenSCAD.

Some very useful OpenSCAD's features, such as adding text using custom font, are not yet available in the official release. I downloaded the latest nightly build and used it since. I designed my libraries with it. Unfortunately, it seems that I'm using a feature that is not yet available in the latest official release. I will see what I can do to fix that.

The main objective of this object was to try my "helix_extrude" and my "bezier" libraries with a real life object.

title: Fortune Bearing Lightsaber Key Chain (Star Wars)

description.text:
Combined the original lightsaber design by Tagoscha (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1768383) with threads from Mike Mattala's NUT JOB (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647), to make a two colour wisdom bearing gift for my Star Wars loving neighbour.

On a little rolled up fortune cookie-like piece of paper (not in the pictures) inside the handle it said: "Do. Or do not. There is no try".

I started sanding the top a little bit, but didn't think that made it a lot nicer, so i stopped after not too long. I didn't sand the handle, since i think the lines quite nicely fit the shape.

Realized part of a sticker for another piece I made fit perfectly, that also gave it an extra 'real' or 'this came from a shop, not my neighbours printer'-feel.

And of course I've added the key ring.

title: BL Touch Mount for Dual Bowden A8

description.text:
Mount for the BL Touch sensor.
The mount is meant to allow the BL Touch sensor to be added to my A8 Dual Bowden setup without having to reprint any of the major parts. It slips in behind the fans.
It prints without support.
The mount is design with all the specified mounting dimension built in. I did not have to use any shims or do any sanding to get the mount at the proper height. I recommend slowing your print speed down and using the best resolution your printer is capable of doing. This should help make the mount as accurate as possible.

Using this sensor allows you to remove the servo/Z sensor from the rear of the carriage. This should give you slightly more X travel and print area.

The mount should place the sensor at X -26.98, Y -26.8 from the left extruder nozzle.
I used X -27, Y -27. You will have to carefully set the Z offset based on your nozzle height.

Double check your wiring and polarity before wiring the new sensor up. I used the same wires from the rear servo and switch.

Dual Bowden conversion: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1733096

I'll add some pictures of the mount on my machine shortly.

EDIT: I added some pictures.

description.text:
A small shelf to raise an electric toothbrush charger off of the counter surface. Mounting plate attaches securely to the wall with two 3M Command strips. The charger slips in to the shelf, with the cord slotted through the back, so that it runs through the bottom of the shelf. A cover plate locks the parts together and covers the slot. The entire shelf then slots into the mounting plate for easy removal (e.g. for cleaning)

This version uses 0.3mm tolerances. If you need a version with adjusted tolerances, let me know.

All parts print great without supports and piece together without adhesives. I printed with 15% infill and 3 walls.

title: Spaghetti Measure Spoon (cucchiaio due porzioni)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After a funny comment about Michael's Spaghetti Gauge I came to think of a cooking spoon with a hole that would measure spaghetti for a two person meal.

I used my desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft and a a spiral-toothed 1.5 mm flute and a 30° engraving bit. After sanding on a spindle sander I used olive oil to finish the spoon.

My first try was using beech plywood, but this did not work out. After a few applications the layers dissolved.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

I have not tried to print the stl as I am not sure about the robustness of the material.

author: ZenziWerken

description.text: My daughter asked me if I could print a chair big enough for her to sit in. Challenge accepted. I designed a snap fit joint for the legs and posts (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:218949), then made the seat and back rest the maximum size that I could print on my Replicator 2. My daughter loved the chair, but quickly grew out if it. Now she uses it as a chair for her stuffed animals.

Sliced at Medium quality in Makerware (0.2 mm layer height, 10% infill). Printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA.  
Warping was a big problem on the seat and back rest. I had to level the build plate carefully before each print.  
Once all the parts were printed, the legs and back posts snap into the seats and back rest. It takes a bit a force to get them in, but once there in, it's a snug fit.

description.text:
After trying some of the 40mm shrouds available, I decided to design one for my own needs.

  • Full access to the hot end. I do change nozzles often and don't want to remove the shroud each time.
  • To be printed in polycarbonate or ABS. I got issues with other versions in these materials. Walls to thick to flex without damage. This one does it. No issues after several removal/installing actions.

Made to cut M3 thread in the holes. Or you'll need a drill to size it for M3.

The shroud is asymmetrical. Highest end should be on top.

Print
Version from the pictures has been printed in ABS (next one will be in PC)
Nozzle 0,6mm, layer 0,32, support needed. I've printed it with the fan side on the bed.

S3D factory file added

Hello!

Something that can automatically generate a turbine or propeller? This OpenSCAD script does just that! Generate very quickly a parametrised turbine or propeller. Arguably the best one on thingiverse?

It is quite complete, here I list its features:

  1. Clockwise/ Counter Clockwise rotation
  2. Leading edge of blade can be curve (an Arc) or straight. A module is created to generate arcs (OpenSCAD can't draw Arc primitives)
  3. Trailing edge blade can curve inwards (I call it 'convex') or outward ('concave') and this can be defined with an exponentiation function (you decide the base or power)
    See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponentiation
  4. There's an offset parameter, allowing you to prescribe, when curvature begins (applied)...
  5. Of course, number of blades, length, height, thickness, stem radius, shaft radius, etc...

I've uploaded a few samples of what was generated. Including photos of actual prints.

The smallest print is a micro wind turbine generator, with 1mm thickness blade, which works very well (^_^)b

From experimentation, the larger prints tends to be worst in terms of balance, for use as fan, best use 'concave' blades, as a turbine, best use 'convex', print as structurally light as possible. Larger doesn't always mean better.

Low blade pitch (<40deg) definitely requires support for prints, any other way to print without support???

Export from OpenSCAD CSG format to FreeCAD for further edits...
https://www.freecadweb.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_CSG

Preview (F5) can be very slow and even freezes OpenSCAD (so always hit the save button!), so set your rendering layer height to x10 of print height, when previewing your design!

NB: Within the script, concave and convex selection, required you to block comment out either, so take note!

NB: I'm no expert in turbine theory and design, so feel free to correct and improve (mansplain) if you like , and please post your updates! Thanks!

Decided to make some Grateful Dead themed coasters for a friend's birthday. I printed these with Hatchbox Wood filament. Coaster dimensions are 4.75 in OD x .15 in thickness for the larger version (pictured) and 4 in OD x .13 in thickness for the smaller. Enjoy!

One print setting that will make the top surface smoother is to have thicker top and bottom layers, I believe my top and bottom layers were .75 mm for a .15 mm layer height (so 5 layers).

comments.text: This thing at 100% is extremely small. Recommend scaling up to 2000% if you want a coaster sized print. Have not printed the holder yet, but I suspect it would benefit from the same treatment.

My sister asked me to make Angel Fish cake toppers for her wedding.  
Challenge accepted.  
I designed it in Openscad and printed on a Replicator 2. I then made a Silicone mold and cast it using polyester casting resin to get different colors and glitter. She ended up going with the blue metal flake version.

Sliced at Medium quality in Makerware (0.2 mm layer height, 10% infill). Printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA.  
I then made a mold using OOMOO 30 and then cast replicas using Castin' Craft polyester resin.

title: Lasercut RPG Combat Counters - 6mm MDF Arch A Format
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of simple round 25mm or 1" counters that I normally use as space fillers for my lasercut projects. Includes the numbers 1-30, the normal "Arabic" alphabet and Roman numerals 1 thru 10. Produces a handful of handy dandy counters for the organization of combats or encounters on your gaming table. Simplify accounting of long lists of combatants. When an enemy or allied combatant expires, you can flip the counter accordingly to symbolize it's demise. A friend ordered a set cut in 6mm MDF because he likes the beefy tactile feel over 3mm MDF. You can choose your own preference for material and thickness. The sheet comes with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 12" x 9" (Arch A sheet size) - four of these would fit within an (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size or across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

description.text:
I've been using a build plate sheet (LokBuild - other brands are available...) since I received their KickStarter reward and I've been very happy with bed adhesion, print removal and not needing to re-tape and re-glue. I've noticed one new problem though - colour "memory" from old prints. Bold colours left on the bed stick to new prints meaning that clean white prints get spoilt.

When the brim from an old print has been very thin it can be tricky to scrape all the old filament off the bed. This is mainly caused by the nozzle being too close, resulting in a film of filament rather than a bead but the end result is that future prints need to be located carefully to miss the dirty bits.

My solution is to print a thin square over the whole bed and deliberately grab all the old colours. I've found that one print is usually enough, though some filament pigment (red in particular) needs a second pass.

The two photos show the problem and solution. - a red arc on the rectangular plate was hardly visible on a reprint (not shown). You can see how much old filament has been lifted off in the big photo and also (bottom half of the photo) where the previous print has already cleaned the bed.

Notes:

Print using your favourite settings but don't use a brim if you're printing near to the bed edge. Or near to glass clips...

I used about 8m of filament - a spool end of white seems most suitable.

Edit May 17 - Ignore the photos if you're looking at the bed cleaner, I've posted them in order to answer http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/anet-a8-prusa-i3/topic:15481

OpenScad

cube([180,180,0.5],center=true);

Simplest thing you ever did see.

Make sure the square is big enough to cover the area you print to. Thickness only needs to be 2 or 3 layers. Too thin and it'll be tricky to remove, too thick and you'll waste time and filament.

title: Canon EOS M-Series Lens Hood
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Petal type wide angle Lens Hood for Canon EOS M series lenses.

20-30$ saved in comparison to canon's name brand hood, because at the end of the day their plastic is the same as my plastic. However, whats not the same is this hood is 3mm thick making it stronger and more durable than canon's 1.5mm thick hood.

Why should you use a lens hood?

Using a lens hood can take your photos to the next level. They stop lens flare, resulting in sharper images with better contrast that visually pop and look cleaner. Most professionals say "you should always have a hood on your camera for better images no matter where and what you're shooting, unless you want lens flare of course." In addition, the hood provides added protection against bumps and brushes by acting as a buffer zone. It is reverseable for compact storage, and also works with the orignal lens caps, and added filters.
